<asset_id>oceania_stats_map_main</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>core_stats_map</role> <aspect_ratio>16:10</aspect_ratio> <description>Central Oceania map with country fills and high/low stat icons (as shown in proof). Source vector/raster not provided; uses xlsx palette as intended reference.</description> </map_asset> </map_assets> </continent_stats_map> <featurettes> <featurette> <featurette_id>ft1_convicts_to_citizens</featurette_id> <display_title>From Convicts to Citizens—The Story of Australia’s Settlement</display_title> <title>From Convicts to Citizens</title> <subtitle>The Story of Australia’s Settlement</subtitle> <body_text>Imagine a land so distant that the British once sent their prisoners there to start new lives. When the First Fleet landed in Australia in 1788, it turned the coastline into a place of hard work and survival. Convicts built roads and towns, not knowing their labor would shape a new nation. Over time, free settlers arrived, gold was discovered, and cities blossomed into thriving communities. But this growth came at a cost: Indigenous peoples lost their lands, traditions, and even their children. Today, Australia acknowledges these painful truths and celebrates a multicultural society. It’s a nation still learning from its past, embracing its many cultures, and moving forward with a spirit of understanding and respect.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_left_top</layout_slot_id> header image.</description> <hyperlinks> <featurette_id>ft2_urban_life_down_under</featurette_id> <display_title>Urban Life Down Under— The Growth of Cities in Australia and New Zealand</display_title> <title>Urban Life Down Under</title> <subtitle>The Growth of Cities in Australia and New Zealand</subtitle> <body_text>Picture Sydney’s sparkling harbor and Auckland’s busy streets: these cities grew from tiny outposts into vibrant hubs full of art, business, and ideas. Waves of newcomers brought fresh traditions, foods, and languages, turning urban life in Oceania into a colorful patchwork of cultures. Today, sleek skyscrapers rise alongside quiet parks. Museums, festivals, and universities attract people from all over the globe. At the same time, city planners tackle big questions like how to make housing affordable and transportation greener. The result is modern, multicultural cities that celebrate both Indigenous heritage and global connections— places where history and innovation come together every day.</body_text> Cities vs Rest' chart.</layout_notes> </chart> </chart_spec> </featurette> <featurette> <featurette_id>ft3_islands_on_the_edge</featurette_id> <display_title>Islands on the Edge— Sea Level Rise in Micronesia</display_title> <title>Islands on the Edge</title> <subtitle>Sea Level Rise in Micronesia</subtitle> <body_text>In the crystal-clear waters of Micronesia, gentle waves lap at the shores of tiny islands. But as Earth’s climate warms, these islands face a rising threat: higher seas that wash away land and seep into drinking water. Imagine losing not just your home, but also the stories, songs, and traditions that connect your people to the place they’ve known for centuries Micronesians are taking action—planting mangroves, building sea walls, and speaking up at global meetings to protect their homelands. While they contribute little to climate change, they feel its effects deeply. Their courage and voices remind us that we share one Earth, and helping each other adapt is part of caring for our world.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_right_top</layout_slot_id> <assets> and a small map.</layout_notes> </chart> </chart_spec> </featurette> <featurette> <featurette_id>ft4_facing_natures_fury</featurette_id> <display_title>Facing Nature’s Fury—Volcanoes and Cyclones in Oceania</display_title> <title>Facing Nature’s Fury</title> <subtitle>Volcanoes and Cyclones in Oceania</subtitle> <body_text>Oceania sits in a restless part of our planet, where Earth’s plates shift and giant storms brew over warm seas. Volcanoes rumble, and cyclones roar through islands scattered across the Pacific. Yet people here have found ways to live in tune with nature’s power. They build homes designed to bend with the wind and hold practice drills to stay safe when the ground shakes. From ancient myths explaining volcanic fire to modern warning systems that save lives, these communities blend old knowledge with new science. They remind us that living with nature’s fury can make us wiser, kinder, and more prepared for whatever tomorrow brings.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_right_bottom</layout_slot_id> <assets> <asset> <asset_id>ft4_photo_traditional_village_header</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>header_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>16:9</aspect_ratio> <description>Header photo in proof showing a traditional village/thatched structures (within Featurette 4 frame).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url nil="true"/> <url_candidates> <url>https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/61f9387d5d6ccdbcf8484bac21810a1e96cb9d16/0_300_4000_2400/master/4000.jpg?width=1200&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=54c2d2fb7666d8e01cd4dc305fd49cd2</url> <url>https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/3faabfbea4363df3c71ba8989b02bf63a3f80bf2/0_486_4947_2968/master/4947.jpg?width=620&dpr=2&s=none&crop=none</url> </url_candidates> <anchor_texts> <anchor_text>traditional </anchor_text> <anchor_text>built</anchor_text> </anchor_texts> <source_doc>Oceania Featurettes.docx</source_doc> </hyperlinks> <notes> <item>Docx links under 'Diagram: How traditional houses are built...' may be related;
